text:
Brexit would cost North East universities £29m claim university bosses 05:30, 10 Jun 2016 By Jonathan Walker University bosses join the campaign to keep Britain in the European Union as they outline their case against Brexit Shares Get daily news by email Lord John Shipley 
Universities across the North East received more than £29m in research grants and contracts from EU sources last year, it has been revealed. 
And that money would be put at risk if the nation votes to leave the European Union in the referendum on June 23, according to university bosses. 
The warning comes from Universities UK, the body which represents universities across the country. 
It has entered the debate with less than two weeks to go before the historic vote. 
An analysis by Universities UK found that colleges in Newcastle alone received £17.29m of research funding from EU sources in the last financial year. 
Across the North East as a whole, the figure is £29.1m. 
There are 633 jobs in the region which depend on EU research grants, including 364 directly employed in universities. 
And university research contributes to the wider economy, academic leaders said. 
The Armstrong Building at Newcastle University 
Industries in the North East that have benefited most from this knock-on impact include manufacturing, wholesale and retail trade and services to businesses. 
Projects receiving funding include RD-Connect at Newcastle University which provides a central resource for doctors and researchers working on rare genetic diseases to share data, make new discoveries and diagnose more patients. 
It’s hard for doctors to develop the expertise to diagnose and treat rare diseases because they see them so rarely. However, the Newcastle-based scheme allows them to share knowledge with other doctors across Europe. 
Hanns Lochmüller, Professor of Experimental Myology at the Newcastle University John Walton Muscular Dystrophy Research Centre and honorary consultant with the Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Trust, said: “EU funding is absolutely vital to our medical research work at Newcastle University. 
“Of course the number of jobs it has brought into the region is substantial, but what is even more important to me and the patients who come to our centre is that it enables us to run world-leading clinical trials for rare muscle-wasting conditions, provide the best care, and develop cutting-edge ways of diagnosing patients who do not know the cause of their disease.” 
As the EU debate continued, a former leader of Newcastle City Council warned that leaving the EU would be “a massive own goal disrupting our economy and the livelihoods of very many households”. 
John Shipley, now a Liberal Democrat member of the House of Lords, said in a speech in Parliament: “The North East would lose access to hundreds of millions of pounds of EU funding for regional development. 
“The North East needs access to the EU single market of 500 million people, with a say over the rules of doing business across Europe. That means more jobs and more financial security for our region.” 
Tom Watson MP 
Labour Deputy Leader Tom Watson will today publish a dossier setting out what he says will be the impact of leaving the European Union on family budgets. 
He will claim that social security cuts and tax rises totalling more than £18bn would be introduced. 
But there was a boost for the leave campaign as the head of a major British manufacturer said industry would benefit by leaving the EU. 
JCB chairman Lord Bamford, a Tory peer, has written to all JCB employees to explain why he is in favour of quitting the EU. 
The businessman says he supported joining the Common Market but did not back it turning into a political union. 
Stating that more than half of Britain’s trade is with non-EU countries, Lord Bamford warns that the EU has a shrinking share of world trade. 
“No one can be certain of the outcome. One thing I am certain of is this: JCB will continue to trade with Europe irrespective of whether we remain or leave the EU. 
“JCB was selling into Europe long before the UK joined the Common Market in 1973, and it will remain an important market for JCB,” Lord Bamford wrote. 
The JCB chairman told workers it was up to them how they voted, but they should vote one way or the other in the referendum. The European Union debate
